utterances: Simply put, it is past time to talk about starting negotiations.
It is time to move forward.
It is time to show the flexibility and common sense and sense of compromise that's necessary to achieve our goals.
The president then addedâ€¦
Despite all the obstacles, despite all the history, despite all the mistrust, we have to find a way forward.
We have to summon the will to break the deadlock that has trapped generations of Israelis and Palestinians in an endless cycle of conflict and suffering.
We cannot continue the same pattern of taking tentative steps forward and then stepping back.
Still, there were no assurances or commitments to resume talks, though following the photo-op, these leaders held one more meeting, this time all three of them together.
The president's special envoy to the Middle East, former Senator George Mitchell, says the fact that that final session even took place is very positive.
This was the first meeting between Israelis and Palestinians at this level in nearly a year.
Even nine months ago, such a meeting did not seem possible.
But the Middle East is also a reminder that despite President Obama's popularity around the world, such problems are as difficult and vexing as ever.
The president's day Tuesday also included a sit down with China's President Hu.
The U.S.
and China are currently involved in a trade dispute over imported Chinese-made tires.
A trade war may still erupt.
A White House official said the topic came up, there remained differences, but he said both sides have agreed to consult closely to avoid future disputes.
He said they did talk about how to address the threat posed by North Korea's nuclear weapons and the belief that Iran is trying to develop such weapons.
President Obama's final event yesterday was the fifth annual Clinton Global Initiative Conference hosted by former President Bill Clinton.
Ladies and gentlemen, I'm going to follow protocol.
You know what it is?
It's my high honor to present the president of the United States.
(Soundbite of applause)
The Clinton conference this year is focusing on the global economic downturn and its impact on everything from world poverty to education to efforts to address climate change.
Mr. Obama praised the organization for the work it has done.

The greenhouse gasses you've cut, the entrepreneurs you've empowered with microloans, all the people, many of them children, you've helped to lead healthier, more productive lives, more than 200 million in more than 150 countries.
That's the meaning of service.
That's the difference we can make.
Expect that theme to play a role in the president's speech to the U.N.
General Assembly later this morning.
Don Gonyea, NPR News, New York.
If you're finding money scarce, you might check out a really, really free market.
No money changes hands, there's not even any barter.
NPR's Margot Adler visited one at a church in New York City.
The Really, Really Free Markets held at Judson Church this past Sunday looks part flee market or garage sale without the money, part party.
Here's the idea: You bring stuff to give away, you take stuff.
There are tables filled with clothing, books, toys, odds and ends.
I recognize a high school kid who lives in my building four miles away.
His name is Sam Smith.
I brought some Stephen King books and I brought a lot of clothes from my mom, from me, and from my brother.
On one table I see some envelopes of a very unusual size.
I slip five of them into my bag.
Sam Imperatrici has been helping to organize the market.
She says it's like Christmas, or like walking into a candy store where everything is free.
It's going to put clothes on your back, food in your belly, people have found housemates.
The goods and services are, you know, the anchor, but in a lot of ways it's that connectivity between people that can happen when you take the exchange of money out of the picture.
Besides clothes and books there are people cutting hair, giving dental advice, writing poems for people.
A young man named McKenzie Mott(ph) is having his face painted to look like a lion.
Are you enjoying getting your face painted?
I am.
It's awesome.
He has no idea what he looks like.
Nope.
Do you care?
Nope, I'm enjoying the experience though.
Now we need the roar.
(Makes roar sound)
The Really, Really Free Market started around 2004, an anarchist response that was part of the anti-globalization movement.
There are free markets from Georgia to California.
Thaddeus Davidson(ph), also known as Thaddeus Umster(ph), stands by the welcome table.
He says the market started as a kind of opposite of a protest.
It's not like we're against this, we're against this.
It's like this is the other side of that coin.
This is what we're for.
And what exactly are they for?
Well, he says, different people imagine a free anarchist economy in different ways.
In small towns where dogfighting is a tradition, Corenfield says top trainers and breeders are established members of the community.
This is basically an example of a gift economy, where everything is freely given and there's no bartering, there's no haggling, there's no money.
Of course, most of these items were bought and sold at one point.
So far all of this seems pretty easy until I get to the food table.
Oh, look at this - gorgeous zucchinis being poured onto the salad.
There are drinks and homemade breads and bananas and bowls of nuts and dried fruits.
Cindy Rosin tells me the bananas and bread were donated from Trader Joe's.
And then a lot of the other food was pretty much rescued, all the salad stuff, all of the crackers, all that rescued from retail garbage.
We waste so much food, she says.
It looked great.
The salad looked fresh and clean, but I confess, I stuck to the nuts.
Maybe next time.
Margot Adler, NPR News, New York.
It's Morning Edition from NPR News.
Good morning, I'm Steve Inskeep.
And I'm Renee Montagne.
In one of our memos to the incoming president, we reported yesterday that the Bush administration has hired corporations to do more of the government's work than ever before - twice as much in fact.
And the government's own investigations reveal that some of those corporate contracts have wasted money or bungled the job.
President-elect Barack Obama says he wants public employees to take back some of that work.
But as NPR's Daniel Zwerdling reports, Mr. Obama can expect to face obstacles.
The Bush administration had barely invaded Iraq and there were controversies swirling around its contracts.
(Soundbite of CBS News broadcast)
This document, part of a whistle-blower lawsuit obtained by CBS News, alleges a blueprint of contractor abuse in Iraq detailing how the government was billed 10 times more than it should have been.
Of course, the military has always hired contractors to support the troops.
They make tanks and planes and ready-to-eat meals.
But the administration has gone way beyond that.
There are more contractors handling the war in Iraq than U.S.
troops.
Some are making the kinds of decisions that government employees used to make.
And the dependence on contractors in Iraq echoes what's happening here at home.
For instance, guess who's helping coordinate the nation's strategy at the Centers for Disease Control to fight the flu and food-borne outbreaks.
A recent government report said that more than half the employees in the office that handles it are corporate contractors.
Homeland Security depends so much on contractors that they hired contractors to supervise the other contractors.
We've always thought of the government as motivated by a sense of service to the people.
We're getting away from that.
Congress appointed Charles Tiefer earlier this year to a new commission that oversees Pentagon contracts.
Tiefer says obviously some government employees do a bad job, and some contractors do a great job.
But he says federal workers have to swear an oath to defend the Constitution, just like soldiers do.
Not contractors.
These contractors, they're not under the normal democratic accountability at all.
Contractors are motivated by the dollar.
As you might have heard yesterday, I went to one of the president's top aides, and I asked, why have you turned so much to industry?
It has not been the result of a philosophical mandate to contract out more of the government's work.
